channel.title: Series on Tushar Chandra
channel.description: Recent content in Series on Tushar Chandra

item.title: What I read this week (January 19 - 25)
item.description: Articles I read this week, including “data science is different now” and a Washington Post editorial about regulating AI.

item.title: What I read this week (January 12 - 18)
item.description: Articles I read this week, including “goodbye clean code,” the Neural ODEs paper retrospective, and technical writing.

item.title: Software engineering is an essential part of data science
item.description: Good software engineering is an indispensible part of good data science. I've believed this for a while, but only recently come to feel strongly about it, and this post goes into more detail on why.

item.title: Paper: 'This Post Will Just Get Taken Down': Characterizing Removed Pro-Eating Disorder Content on Social Media
item.description: This is a social computing paper analyzing characteristics of over 30,000 pro-eating disorder (pro-ED) posts that were removed from Instagram after having been public at one time. The authors built a classifier for removed pro-ED posts against non-removed ones, and also studied the characteristics of removed posts more generally.

item.title: What I read this week (January 5 - 11)
item.description: Articles I read this week, including predictions for 2020 and FiveThirtyEight's primary methodology.

item.title: Comparing my old and new sites
item.description: I migrated my site a couple of days ago. What are some of the differences, both feature-wise and visually? I'll compare common actions on both.

item.title: What I read this week (December 29 - January 4)
item.description: Articles I read this week, including the future of the web and different ways of conveying information, thoughts on the current state of software, and more.

item.title: Paper: Competition and Crowd-out for Brand Keywords in Sponsored Search
item.description: Another paper on digital search advertising, this one on the effects of competition on ads placed on brand keyword searches. This was another study reacting to the eBay study on own-brand advertising. Published in the Marketing Science journal, the paper is available here. The authors are Andrey Simonov, Chris Nosko, and Justin Rao.

item.title: Paper: Firms' Reactions to Public Information on Business Practices: Case of Search Advertising
item.description: This is a paper evaluating the effects of the infamous eBay online advertising experiment, in which eBay pulled millions of dollars of own-brand advertising and saw no measurable effect on web traffic. The study (using data from Bing) evaluated how other companies reacted to this news.

item.title: Migrating to Hugo
item.description: Hello, Hugo! This post marks the first one written specifically for the new version of my site, built with Hugo. In this post, I'll outline some of the reasons for switching to Hugo and talk about the process of moving everything over.

item.title: Reading List
item.description: This is a page of things I'm hoping to read soon. It includes papers and blog posts, along with talks and other forms of media. Things at the top of each section have been around for longer, and there's no real order to when I'll get around to each item (if ever). This page is mostly for my own reference.

item.title: Resume
item.description: I'm currently a data scientist at Nielsen. I did my master's in computer science and undergrad in computer science and the Integrated Science Program, both at Northwestern (go ‘cats!). My email address is me@(this domain).

item.title: Paper: Discrimination in the Age of Algorithms (2/2)
item.description: Part 2 of the summary of the paper by Jon Kleinberg, Jens Ludwig, Sendhil Mullainathan, and Cass R Sunstein, published in the Journal of Legal Analysis. View part 1 here.

item.title: Paper: Discrimination in the Age of Algorithms (1/2)
item.description: Summary of the paper by Jon Kleinberg, Jens Ludwig, Sendhil Mullainathan, and Cass R Sunstein, published in the Journal of Legal Analysis (yeah, a law journal, we'll see how reading this goes).

item.title: Blaise Aguera y Arcas: Social Intelligence (NeurIPS 2019)
item.description: This is my summary of the talk by Blaise Augera y Arcas at NeurIPS 2019, Social Intelligence.

item.title: What I read this week (December 22 - 28)
item.description: Articles I read this week, including posts on AI bias, life without cell phones, and regulating AI.

item.title: Celeste Kidd: How to Know (NeurIPS 2019)
item.description: This is a summary of Celeste Kidd's invited talk at NeurIPS 2019, How to Know, plus some thoughts at the end.

item.title: Reflections on ImageNet bias in the news
item.description: This post is a reflection on two articles, The viral app that labels you isn't quite what you think and AI is biased. Here's how scientists are trying to fix it, both from Wired.

item.title: What I read this week (December 15 - 21)
item.description: Summaries of articles and blog posts that I've read this week, including articles on NeurIPS and many short posts.

item.title: Paper: Me, My Echo Chamber, and I: Introspection on Social Media Polarization
item.description: Summary of the paper by Nabeel Gillani, Ann Yuan, Martin Saveski, Soroush Vosoughi, Deb Roy. View it on arXiv.
